description.narrative: This proposed project's aim is to derive a contextualized multi-sector Coping Strategy Index (CSI) for Afghanistan that is suitablefor use in assessing the need for intervention and monitoring the impact of multi-sector emergency response programmes, which includes the Multipurpose Cash Grants (MPCGs), and which has been rigorously tested to ensure validity as a proxy of overall household stress. The CSI will include strategies which are easily measurable and as objectively verifiable as possible to support accuracy of field data. Furthermore, the process of constructing the CSI will be carried out in such a way to generate support for a harmonized use of the product within the wider humanitarian community in Afghanistan. The work will also provide theopportunity to study whethera single multi-sector CSI is feasible for use by aid agencies in Afghanistan and where variances occur. The methodology for creation of a multi-sector CSI for Afghanistan requires a consultative approach with the broader humanitarian community, combined with bothqualitative and quantitative methods at the field level. The task is to identify, on the one hand, a wide number of potential coping strategies, and on the other hand, a set of concrete traditional sector based indicators against which the performance of these strategies can be judged and validated. Identifying both of these requires: buy in at the coordination level and consultation with donors and response agencies; a piece of qualitative work at the community level to generate genuine ideas for realistic and relevant coping strategies across various contextual settings in Afghanistan; and a quantitative survey to complement the qualitative piece once the potential coping strategies are identified and narrowed down. This survey, with a range of samples taken across the country, is meant to enable analysis of the strategies which are most valid for use as a proxy of overall household stress

participating-org.narrative:
ASSISTANCE FOR HEALTH, EDUCAITON AND DEVELLOPMENT - AHEAD Established in 2008; AHEAD is a non-governmental, non-political and non-for profit organization aims to contribute in improvement of public health, social development, civil society development and education standards improvement. AHEAD started its journey of serving Afghanistan in 2008 by provision of short and medium term trainings to employees of public and private sector in the areas of Financial Management, Business Management and Supervisory Skills; These activities were all funded by private funds of the board of governors / founders of AHEAD. Followed by the initial activity in 2008, AHEAD has until now implemented over 40 small and large-scale projects funded by major donors in Afghanistan.
AHEAD has years of experience working in high-risk areas and would most likely continue operations through their existing networks to the degree possible regardless of shifts in security threat levels. Oxfam and its partners have a customized approach to proceed with caution and navigate through insecure areas. Main areas of AHEAD expertise is contain or has ability to deliver Education and Capacity Building, Private Sector Development, Humanitarian Services, Health Sector, IDP Profiling, Monitoring and Physical Verification, Justice and Human Rights, Surveys and Researches, Livelihood.
Oxfam Novib has provided support to AHEAD for Humanitarian Projects for several years entailing the following aspects of development: encouraging and facilitating return of refugees; rehabilitating and; creating employment and livelihood opportunities; facilitating socio-economic reintegration; and ensuring the participation of local communities in the rural rehabilitation activities. Major components covered with Oxfam Novib support have included: the rehabilitation of rural infrastructure; food security; water supply; and vocational training. The projects have served tens of thousands of families. All theseservices were found useful in the direction of accomplishing broader objectives of alleviating poverty and fostering peace in Afghanistan
